subject: Re: [junit] Question about Interdependent Test Cases
msgSnippet: ... There are a few options, depending on the kind of tests you re running. 1. Change your tests so that they can run independently. This is the best overall
messageBody:
>So said Leonardo Abreu de Barros on 2003-06-30 --------------------
>Hi all,
>
>I have a simple question about arranging related tests inside a test
>case:
>
>- Let`s say I have three tests that in some way depend on each other:
>for example, a creation, a getter and a deletion method.
>These are distinct functionalities, and thus deserve to be on
>separate tests. The problem is: if one fails, the other two will run
>anyway. But if the creation or getter methods fail, it doesn`t make
>sense for me to test the deletion method, as it depends on the
>correctness of the other two. I know calling one test inside another
>is not recommended. What should I do in this case?

There are a few options, depending on the kind of tests you're running.

1. Change your tests so that they can run independently. This is the best overall approach.

2. Make your test fixture "self-repairing". Add logic to your test fixture so that it puts itself into the expected state even when a test fails. If you can do this, then you can probably do #1.

3. Place your tests into one, single test. You lose the ability to report on each test separately, but then I would argue that you really have one large test and not three smaller tests.

One question to ask: what are you trying to test? If you are testing business logic that, as a side-effect, calls these methods you mention, then separate data access from business logic. If you are testing your integration with a database, then you may be testing the database driver and not your code!

I hope this helps.
